abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Coffee Sector Project in Burundi. The
            primary objective of the project was to improve the earning
            ability of Burundi coffee, the country's principal
            export crop. Although the project had a good start,
            implementation of the institutional reform program was
            delayed by one year owing to political resistance within the
            Government. The Bank's performance can be assessed as
            marginally satisfactory. The performance of the Borrower was
            generally satisfactory particularly with regard to adhering
            to the covenants of the Credit Agreement. The overall
            outcome of the project could be considered as marginally
            satisfactory. It achieved a number of institutional
            restructuring and development objectives including a
            substantial increase in the proportion of fully washed
            coffee for exports, resulting in increased export earnings.
            Key lessons learned: (a) although this was not a stated
            objective of the project, attention could have been given,
            in the design of the project, to the organization of farmer
            representation on the Board of the Office du Café (OdC); (b)
            The risk of overly bureaucratic behavior of the newly
            created entities could have been avoided by introducing a
            more competitive environment. (c) Project financed research
            would have been more productive if, alongside the
            traditional agricultural research, efforts had been directed
            towards identifying and eliminating commercial constraints.
            (d) The impact of the training program was affected by poor
            selection of trainees resulting in a mismatch between
            training needs of the individuals and the training offered.
            However the lasting value of the training depends on
            personnel stability. More stringent and clearer regulations
            and selection criteria should have been adopted, especially
            for the overseas training. (e) Utilization and the
            management of the appropriate technical assistance not only
            supports the project but works as a capacity building tool.
            (f) If the coffee production is to be high in both quantity
            and quality, training and extension should be integrated
            into the sector and made its responsibility.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Coffee Sector Project, which will be
            implemented over a five year period, has as its principal
            objective the improvement of the earning ability of Burundi
            coffee, the country's principal export crop.  To
            achieve this the project will : a) implement a package of
            institutional and financial reforms to improve the
            efficiency of the industry, while opening it up to private
            investors; and b) increase the coffee export value through
            investments in coffee washing stations, coffee research and
            training.  Major actions will include : 1) creation of a
            regulatory authority ( Office du Cafe ) to replace the
            present OCIBU; 2) establishment of 5 autonomous companies (
            SOGESTALs ) specialized in the management of coffee washing
            stations and 1 autonomous company ( SODECO ) to operate the
            existing two hulling factories; these companies as well as
            the washing stations, will be open to private ownership; 3)
            establishment of an Assets Management Facility to centralize
            the administration of Government owned physical assets in
            the industry; 4) establishment of an incentive based payment
            system for producers and intermediaries and, for the
            Government, establishment of a direct export tax; and 5)
            establishment of a parallel export marketing facility for
            private exporters to compete with the state owned BCC.
